greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of integers between n^2 and (n+1)^2 that are the sum of two squares; multiple representations are counted once.
comment: Related to the circle problem, cf. A077770. See A077774 for a more restrictive case. A077768 counts the representations multiply.

Number of integers k in range [n^2, ((n+1)^2)-1] for which 2 = the least number of squares that add up to k (A002828). Because of this interpretation a(0)=0 was prepended to the beginning. - _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 04 2016
link: T. D. Noe (terms 1..1000) & Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1024
example: a(8)=6 because 65=64+1=49+16, 68=64+4, 72=36+36, 73=64+9, 74=49+25 and 80=64+16 are between squares 64 and 81. Note that 65 is counted only once.
mathematica: maxN=100; lst={}; For[n=1, n<=maxN, n++, sqrs={}; i=n; j=0; While[i>=j, j=1; While[i^2+j^2<(n+1)^2, If[i>=j&&i^2+j^2>n^2, AppendTo[sqrs, i^2+j^2]]; j++ ]; i--; j-- ]; AppendTo[lst, Length[Union[sqrs]]]]; lst
program: (define (add intfun lowlim uplim) (let sumloop ((i lowlim) (res 0)) (cond ((> i uplim) res) (else (sumloop (1+ i) (+ res (intfun i)))))))
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Nov 20 2002
ext: Term a(0)=0 prepended by _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 04 2016
